More Actions Daniel has a account Daniel Broderick Market Leader, Southwest at Cushman & Wakefield Cushman & Wakefield Stanford University Greater San Diego Area 500+ 500+ connections Send InMail Dan Broderick is an executive in the commercial real estate industry with a proven track record and experience in M&A, recruiting top talent, growing new business lines, and improving performance in individuals and profit centers. Dan's prior brokerage experience is in excess of $8 billion from 60 transactions across four markets and four product types. As a leading real estate professional in his market for over a 15 years, Dan is well-versed in every aspect of the business including investment banking, capital markets, sales and leasing and corporate services. Dan’s experience and insight in the commercial real estate industry was instrumental in developing Cushman & Wakefield’s Southern California strategic growth initiatives. His proven success in building systems, teams and processes has enhanced the platform and the level of client service. As an award-winner, board member, volunteer and contributor to a myriad of industry, philanthropic and charitable causes, Dan is a well-established community leader. His industry involvement includes serving on the Board of Directors for Stanford Professionals In Real Estate (SPIRE), Board of Directors and past President for the San Diego chapter of NAIOP; a former member of the CRE Policy Advisory Board of the USD Burnham Moores Center for Real Estate; a member of ULI. Dan is a licensed real estate broker in California. See moreSee more of undefined summary Highlights Follow Follow Daniel’s Articles 1,204 followers C&W Infographics: Celebrate the Super Bowl with Super Stats Daniel Broderick on LinkedIn Publish dateFebruary 3, 2017 See all articles Experience Regional Managing Principal, Southwest Company Name Cushman & Wakefield Dates Employed Jul 2013 – Present Employment Duration 4 yrs Location Southern California Dan leads all service lines for the Southwestern Region of Cushman & Wakefield, comprised of more than 550 professionals, in 7 offices, and representing over $150M of revenue. He is responsible for client engagement, revenue growth, developing, training, managing, coaching and transacting with brokers and staff throughout the region. Dan oversees Capital Markets, Occupier Services, Investor Services, Property Management and Project Management in the region. Dan is a leader within the national institutional Investor Services team, and works with a number of strategic accounts.In addition, Dan is responsible for the day-to-day leadership and management of the San Diego market, with nearly 300 professionals in 6 facilities. C&W is the market leader for commercial real estate services firm in San Diego County.Dan led the legacy commercial real estate firm Cassidy Turley San Diego/BRE through the sale and merger to the national firm Cassidy Turley (July 2013), and then as a Board Member of Cassidy Turley he led the Southern California region in the merger with the global platform of DTZ (January 2015). This merger was financed by a consortium led by TPG. Dan's role through the mergers was as strategic leader and manager of the Southern California Region, the third largest economy in the world. He led this region through the merger, integration, brand change and aggressive growth period. He was responsible for recruiting, operations, transactions, client retention, and the P&L performance of the region.Cushman & Wakefield now operates in more than 60 countries around the world and is well positioned in every major market for continued growth. With a tenacious, entrepreneurial, and client-centric culture of highly skilled people behind both firms, the new company will be able to tap into greater resources worldwide to deliver superior results for clients. President & CEO, San Diego Company Name Cassidy Turley / BRE Commercial Dates Employed Mar 2011 – Jul 2013 Employment Duration 2 yrs 5 mos Location San Diego, CA Dan provided the strategic vision and leadership for rebranding and repositioning a regional firm with 170+ professionals. During this time the company increased organic revenue by 13% CAGR, while increasing EBITDA by 83% CAGR, achieving the highest EBITDA in the company's 27 year history. This resulted in the company's turnaround and sale, whereby returning shareholders a 361% increase in equity value and a 4.6 multiple in under three years. This was accomplished by Dan elevating the level of client service, and dramatically enhanced the breadth and depth of capabilities of the platform. Dan successfully recruited talent, he started and developed new service lines (property management and construction management), opened new offices, and created new product specialty areas (Institutional capital markets, senior housing and retail investments). He also moved quickly to divest under-performing entity investments and offices. He implemented an effective Performance Improvement Plan and the "TOP" training and development program. In addition to his passion for real estate, Dan’s passion the community and firm's culture was manifested in the mantra he created, “Client. Community. Culture.” They increased charitable contributions and giving by over 400% and was ranked as San Diego Business Journal as a "Best Places to Work" in 2013. Entrepreneurial, competitive and innovative by nature, Dan leads with a relentless pursuit of cutting-edge processes and results. Senior Vice President Company Name Eastdil Secured / Wells Fargo Dates Employed Apr 2005 – Mar 2011 Employment Duration 6 yrs Location Greater San Diego Area Dan specialized in the advisory services for the dispositions and acquisitions of institutional grade commercial real estate (office, industrial, multifamily, and life science/R&D product). Dan completed over $8.0 billion in transactions, covering the Orange County, San Diego and Phoenix markets. His team was consistently ranked as the top sales teams in each market for assets over $30 million in value. His responsibilities included coordinating the entire process of a transaction, from winning the new business to closing the transaction. He underwrote, analyzed and valued assets; he pitched and prospected for new business; he edited and directed the creation of marketing materials and offering memorandums; and he interacted directly with investors and clients throughout the entire transaction process. Dan managed and coordinated deal-specific teams of professionals. Senior Associate Company Name Burnham Real Estate (now Cushman & Wakefield) Dates Employed Nov 2001 – Mar 2005 Employment Duration 3 yrs 5 mos Location Greater San Diego Area Dan specialized in institutional grade office product in the Mid and North City markets of San Diego County. He participated in landlord and tenant represented lease and sale transactions with total consideration values in excess of $800 million. He was awarded “Rookie of the Year” and the “Civic Leadership” Award. Dan was a part of a hand selected “Strategic Steering Committee” that was comprised of leaders throughout the organization who focused on major company initiatives, including firm culture, training, the company’s “mission” and growth strategies, etc. Some of Dan’s institutional clients included Credit Suisse First Boston, Goldman Sachs, Equity Office Properties (EOP), Crescent Real Estate Equities, and DRA Advisors. Investment Banking - Equity Research Analyst Company Name Bank of America Dates Employed Jun 1999 – May 2000 Employment Duration 1 yr Location San Francisco Bay Area Dan analyzed, valued, and researched the performance and competitive position of prominent, public companies in the home furnishings industry. He presented companies and our research to institutional buyers. He created high-level PowerPoint presentations, and “roadshow decks” to present to institutional buy-side investment firms. He built financial models and charts based on earnings reports and forecasts, to compare and predict various data points. He drafted and formatted quarterly research reports and participated in initial public offerings. He monitored macro-economic trends to predict fluctuations in the retail and manufacturing sectors. Organized by Guy Judkowski and Jordan Talasnik, 16 doubles teams each paid an entry fee and selected a charity of their choice to represent in the tournament. The tournament used a modified Compass Draw, with donations allocated to represented charities based on the order of finish in the tourney. We hope to hold the event every year. For more information about the charities represented and a summary of the day's action, go to http://www.talasniktennis.com/2016-charity-doubles-tournament. She concentrates her practice on school law and labor and employment law, and leads Capehart Scatchard's School Law Blog. Alexis liked A homeless man walks into Philz Coffee here in San Francisco. It's a bit of a grungy place, with a real authentic community vibe. Rather than ask him to leave, a barista says to the guy (who at this point is standing near the coffee ordering line), "Hey Dave, great to see you! Would you like some water this morning? We can get that for you." The man waits in line, just like everyone else, and gets ready for his water order. That was enough goodness for me, but then a manager walks around the counter, goes up to the man in line, and starts taking a breakfast order for him. And it's all happening like it's just another Friday. Life goes on all around them. No biggie. Humanity can be awesome. And when business is done with humanity, well, it seems like everyone wins. Extremely supremely organized Assistant October 25, 2011, Natasha reported directly to Steven Steve Wardell was one of my supervisor's at I.C. Sciences Corporation. It was a pleasure to work with Steve - he was an excellent supervisor, communicator, and mentor. With regard to managing direct reports and day-to-day work-flow, Steve's analytical capabilities and immense intellect shine through in his ability to quickly glean the skill-set best suited to accomplishing the task at hand.Steve is an expert at inspiring a shared vision, but he is also exceptionally talented at enabling others to contribute their best. What I most appreciated about Steve's management style was the effectiveness of his project delegation methods. Not only would Steve take the time to give a thorough over-view of the details, challenges and possible road-blocks ahead, but he would then also allow for full autonomy to research, explore alternatives, and provide solutions within the project timeline. Under Steve's supervision, I was able to offer strategic contributions and professionally develop at a high - and highly rewarding - level.Steve thoroughly understands the importance of communication with regard to laying a foundation prior to launching new initiatives. This understanding is crucial to efficient work-flow from an administrative point of view. Steve's management style is perfectly suited to achieving success on many levels - and most importantly, it allows for a streamlined efficiency that is crucial in the high-demand workflow characteristic of start-ups and other fast-paced environments. Extremely supremely organized Assistant October 25, 2011, Natasha reported directly to Steven Steve Wardell was one of my supervisor's at I.C. Sciences Corporation. It was a pleasure to work with Steve - he was an excellent supervisor, communicator, and mentor. With regard to managing direct reports and day-to-day work-flow, Steve's analytical capabilities and immense intellect shine through in his ability to quickly glean the skill-set best suited to accomplishing the task at hand.Steve is an expert at inspiring a shared vision, but he is also exceptionally talented at enabling others to contribute their best. What I most appreciated about Steve's management style was the effectiveness of his project delegation methods. Not only would Steve take the time to give a thorough over-view of the details, challenges and possible road-blocks ahead, but he would then also allow for full autonomy to research, explore alternatives, and provide solutions within the project timeline. Under Steve's supervision, I was able to offer strategic contributions and professionally develop at a high - and highly rewarding - level.Steve thoroughly understands the importance of communication with regard to laying a foundation prior to launching new initiatives. This understanding is crucial to efficient work-flow from an administrative point of view. Steve's management style is perfectly suited to achieving success on many levels - and most importantly, it allows for a streamlined efficiency that is crucial in the high-demand workflow characteristic of start-ups and other fast-paced environments. He is very prompt in helping out his colleague given 1) his wide sectoral coverage spanning (at one point in time) four sectors and 2) his CA background (unlike most of the rest with the typical engineering + MBA profile). What really differentiates him from others, is his "Can-Do-Approach". Despite having multiple responsibilities, he is always very positive and forthcoming. He always takes the additional pain to go that "extra mile" and is a dream resource for any manager. Given the crazy working hours (at times), it is always a pleasure to have Chunky as a cheerful team mate, spreading his positive energy all around, while churning out insightful company notes for CS's clients. Whilst at GSAM, Khemka set up the Indian-focused equity fund in 2006 and eventually would go on to oversee $5.3bn in emerging-market assets. After 17 years at Goldman's, Khemka believes "there's a lot of interest from foreign investors in Indian equities", and because of this, setting up a fund in "the Indian equity market is home ground for me and it is always good to play with a home advantage". White Oak Capital have assembled a team of eight, and will start operations in August. #SpartanInternational Kulbinder liked Thank you to the Private Placement Life Insurance & Variable Annuities Forum team for having me speak at their conference today in Boston. Highlights Follow Follow Nathan’s Articles & Activity 1,055 followers Why Sky Diving Is The Best Career Advice I've Ever Received Nathan Littlewood on LinkedIn See 4 more articles To all the smaller food brands out there looking to build a presence in the New York City area please avoid a big pitfall that is a distributor named Gourmet Distribution based in Long Island. I had been warned that they had questionable payment history with other brands and that we should keep things tight. We entered skeptically. What I wasn't prepared for was the array of devious lies to separate us from our products without payment. I just hope that my misfortunes can help other food brands to avoid this pitfall. Do not even listen to him. There are lots of good distributors in the area and I would love to help anyone looking for guidance on building distribution in this area. Please reach out. Highlights Follow Follow Nathan’s Articles & Activity 1,055 followers Why Sky Diving Is The Best Career Advice I've Ever Received Nathan Littlewood on LinkedIn See 4 more articles To all the smaller food brands out there looking to build a presence in the New York City area please avoid a big pitfall that is a distributor named Gourmet Distribution based in Long Island. I had been warned that they had questionable payment history with other brands and that we should keep things tight. We entered skeptically. What I wasn't prepared for was the array of devious lies to separate us from our products without payment. I just hope that my misfortunes can help other food brands to avoid this pitfall. Do not even listen to him. There are lots of good distributors in the area and I would love to help anyone looking for guidance on building distribution in this area. Please reach out. Whilst at GSAM, Khemka set up the Indian-focused equity fund in 2006 and eventually would go on to oversee $5.3bn in emerging-market assets. After 17 years at Goldman's, Khemka believes "there's a lot of interest from foreign investors in Indian equities", and because of this, setting up a fund in "the Indian equity market is home ground for me and it is always good to play with a home advantage". White Oak Capital have assembled a team of eight, and will start operations in August. #SpartanInternational Kulbinder liked Thank you to the Private Placement Life Insurance & Variable Annuities Forum team for having me speak at their conference today in Boston. Yan Sun Interpreter and translator，TMCer August 21, 2015, Ken managed Yan directly Yan escorted me as translator/interpreter on a due diligence type visit to a Chinese chemicals company near Jinan in August 2015. Her good work actually began well before the visit, with an exchange of messages to discuss the work involved, and she gathered extensive information on the company in advance, checking technical terms and product names, etc. She also established my key requirements. Yan also helped me with logistics in getting to the local station. Throughout the meetings with the company, Yan was able to provide clear interpretation of what my Chinese counterparts said, but also a great deal of 'reading between the lines' of what was actually said. Cultural issues were also handled by Yan, including gifts (giving and receiving) and lunch/dinners/toasts. Yan also helped with translating what the company's English speakers were saying into Chinese for the benefit of the others.Finally, Yan helped with further travel arrangements. Yan is very competent, quick to learn new industries and meeting formats, works hard to prepare and makes a very good impression on clients. Personally, she is great company and an excellent travel companion. I will be making further use of her services not only in Shandong but anywhere she is able to work with me in China in future. I whole heartedly recommend her as translator/escort interpreterKen Rumph Reena Verma Bhasin, CFA Head - Group Strategy and M&A May 28, 2015, Ken was senior to Reena Verma but didn’t manage directly Reena's knowledge and deep network across both pan-Asian telecoms and materials would have been impressive in two people, let alone one. She is Principal at Alexy Capital Management, a private investment fund she founded in 2005. Cooper currently serves as the COO of Ensogo Limited, a company listed on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX:E88), where his primary focus is managing the liquidation of the company's subsidiaries across 7 jurisdictions in South East Asia. Prior to joining Ensogo, Cooper co-founded ZALORA Group, Asia-Pacific's leading group of online fashion destinations where he served as CFO. Before launching ZALORA Group, Cooper helped build the corporate finance and planning function at Viet Thai International, one of Vietnam’s largest consumer marketing and multi-unit retailers. He began his career at Goldman Sachs in New York City as an equity research analyst covering the Specialty Finance and Insurance sectors. Cooper graduated as a Robertson Scholar from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Duke University with a degree in International Studies focusing on Global Economics, Trade, & Development. my firm decided it was time to restart our research efforts. At the time, no sector research remained. And, as we launched back into the group, I worked closely with Jason on how to think about EQIX and how to think about the broader secular thesis. Together, we created a framework for analyzing performance, projecting revs, flow-thru margins, and the capital expenditures necessary to support that growth. Many of these metrics are the ones that the vast majority of the industry uses today - and, so, in many ways, I view Jason as the grandfather of data center services metric creation. In the time we worked together (from 2003 until today), I have never found a more valuable partner in articulating a company's value proposition to investors - and few better friends. There is no shortage of superlatives I could laud upon Jason - but sufficed to say, he is one of the very best. my firm decided it was time to restart our research efforts. At the time, no sector research remained. And, as we launched back into the group, I worked closely with Jason on how to think about EQIX and how to think about the broader secular thesis. Together, we created a framework for analyzing performance, projecting revs, flow-thru margins, and the capital expenditures necessary to support that growth. Many of these metrics are the ones that the vast majority of the industry uses today - and, so, in many ways, I view Jason as the grandfather of data center services metric creation. In the time we worked together (from 2003 until today), I have never found a more valuable partner in articulating a company's value proposition to investors - and few better friends. There is no shortage of superlatives I could laud upon Jason - but sufficed to say, he is one of the very best. More Actions Lara has a premium account Click to upgrade to Premium Lara Warner Chief Compliance and Regulatory Affairs Officer at Credit Suisse (Group) AG Credit Suisse (Group) AG Penn State University Zürich Area, Switzerland 500+ 500+ connections Connect Pending Invitation Sent Lara J. Warner is the Chief Compliance and Regulatory Affairs Officer and a member of the Executive Boards of Credit Suisse Group and Credit Suisse. From 2013 to 2015, Mrs. Warner was Chief Operating Officer of the Investment Banking division and ad-interim Chief Financial Officer, based in New York, and a member of the Investment Bank Operating Committee. In her role as Chief Compliance and Regulatory Affairs Officer, Mrs. Warner oversees Credit Suisse's compliance with the global regulatory environment, the banks policies and controls, and with her team, manages all compliance issues arising within the bank. From 2010 to 2015, Mrs. Warner was the Chief Financial Officer for the Investment Banking division. Previously, she was the Global Head of Fixed Income and Economic Research, and before that, served as Head of US Equity Research. Mrs. Warner joined Credit Suisse in 2002 as a senior equity research analyst covering the cable television, wireline and wireless telecommunications services and satellite industries. Mrs. Warner served as a member on the Managing Director Evaluation Committee (MDEC) during 2008 and 2009. Prior to joining the Credit Suisse, Mrs. Warner was a senior research analyst at Lehman Brothers, where she covered the cable television industry. Before joining Lehman Brothers in March 2001, Mrs. Warner spent 10 years at AT&T, most recently as Director of Investor Relations and previously as Chief Financial Officer for AT&T's Competitive Local Exchange business unit efforts nationwide. Mrs. Warner is Chair of the Women's Leadership Board of Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government and a Board Member of the Aspen Institute's Business and Society Program. Mrs. Warner holds a B.S. from Pennsylvania State University. Eckerd College Clearwater, Florida 12 12 connections Connect Pending Invitation Sent Harry Katica began his career in the investment industry more than 30 years ago as a research liaison for Raymond James Equity Research. He rose to become a research analyst by 1986, covering Florida-based companies and the specialty retail sector before departing Raymond James in 1997 to cover the specialty retail sector for first Prudential Securities and then Southwest Securities. Mr. Katica was twice recognized in The Wall Street Journal’s Best On The Street survey. Mr. Katica returned to Raymond James as a financial advisor in 2006 and returned to the research liaison office in his current leadership role in 2008. In his current position he seeks to draw upon his diverse experience as both an equity research analyst and retail financial advisor to help make research easier for advisors to use. Mr. Katica graduated from Eckerd College with a B.A. degree in economics with honors and earned his designation as a Chartered Financial Analyst in 1993. Alex liked Marcelo’s photo Alex liked Course focuses on case studies of black business leaders Alex liked This week reminded me why I became a recruiter. A young AM contacted me a while ago and we met. I saw a spark and I never gave up on him. I didn’t have any junior roles on but that didn’t matter. I found opportunities. He flopped his first interview, so we trained on behavioral questions and did some interview prep, he lacked energy because he was working 13 hours a day, so I was his coach and spurred him on. I hated seeing that spark fade. Every time I checked in with him, I reminded him of what I saw and I wouldn’t give up. He has just accepted a role with a company that I introduced him to. It’s perfect and I know they will bring out the best in him. I can't wait to sit on the sidelines and see his career flourish. It's not about the biggest fee it's about the biggest feeling and I feel great that I could help. Alex liked Marcelo’s photo Alex liked Course focuses on case studies of black business leaders Alex liked This week reminded me why I became a recruiter. A young AM contacted me a while ago and we met. I saw a spark and I never gave up on him. I didn’t have any junior roles on but that didn’t matter. I found opportunities. He flopped his first interview, so we trained on behavioral questions and did some interview prep, he lacked energy because he was working 13 hours a day, so I was his coach and spurred him on. I hated seeing that spark fade. Every time I checked in with him, I reminded him of what I saw and I wouldn’t give up. He has just accepted a role with a company that I introduced him to. It’s perfect and I know they will bring out the best in him. I can't wait to sit on the sidelines and see his career flourish. It's not about the biggest fee it's about the biggest feeling and I feel great that I could help. More Actions Kindra has a account Kindra Tatarsky Global Adventurer at Curiosity Chronicles Curiosity Chronicles University of California, Los Angeles San Francisco Bay Area 500+ 500+ connections Send InMail Kindra has spent her career analyzing, investing in and growing businesses that focus on the consumer. The technology-empowered consumer of today is changing the way businesses work, which in turn is creating tremendous opportunity for visionary companies. Whether media, commerce or healthcare, the consumer is looking for experiential engagement, and there are a multitude of companies that are capitalizing on these opportunities. Building on her career in research and investing, Kindra advises investors, enterprise companies and start-ups who are stakeholders in the changing consumer technology landscape. Through a deep understanding of today’s consumer, Kindra is focused on consumer-centric initiatives to accelerate growth for her clients. Tapping into the wealth of global innovation, together we can create solutions that solve company's biggest needs while enhancing the overall consumer experience. Kindra graduated from UCLA with a B.A. in English, and a Business minor, and she holds a CFA certification. When she isn’t following her insatiable curiosity, Kindra finds balance with yoga, cooking, family and friends. She lives with her husband and their two children in Mill Valley, CA, and together their explorations take them on many adventures. See moreSee more of undefined summary Highlights Follow Follow Les’ Articles & Activity 12,184 followers Top Stories from Alpine Investment Review (AIR): November 9, 2016 Les Baquiran on LinkedIn See 36 more articles Their ancestors were slaves sold by Georgetown. Now they're going to school there. Les liked A little food for thought... A group of wolves: The three in front are old & sick, they walk in front to set the pace of the running group lest they get left behind. The next five are the strongest & best, they are tasked to protect the front side if there is an attack. The pack in the middle are always protected from any attack. The five behind them are also among the strongest & best; they are tasked to protect the back side if there is an attack. The last one is the LEADER. He ensures that no one is left behind. He keeps the pack unified and on the same path. He is always ready to run in any direction to protect & serves as the 'bodyguard' to the entire group. Just in case anyone wanted to know what it really means to be a leader. It's not about being out front. It means taking care of the team. He was a consummate professional who blended his duty to the State with a unique flexibility to incorporate new ideas and initiatives to attract attention and interest to the Economy of Nebraska. Rishi liked "The First 30 Days as a Summer Associate" - TD Securities Rishi liked A young man buys a donkey for $100 - but when the farmer delivers it - the donkey is dead and the farmer has spent the money so there is no return of the price paid. "I'll take it anyway and raffle it" says the boy. “You can’t raffle a dead donkey" says the farmer. “Yes I can - I just won’t tell them it's dead" says the boy. A month later the farmer meets the boy asks him what happened. “I sold 500 tickets at $2 a ticket" "Didn't anyone complain?” asks the farmer. “Yes”- the boy replied "Just the man who won... so I gave him his $2 back". The boy is now an investment banker. More Actions Keith has a account Keith Banks President, U.S. Trust, Head of Merrill Lynch & U.S. Trust CIO and Investment Solutions Group U.S. Trust Columbia University in the City of New York New York, New York 500+ 500+ connections Send InMail Since 2008, I have been the president of U.S. Trust, which provides integrated investment, trust, banking and lending services to wealthy and ultra-wealthy clients. U.S. Trust clients are served by teams of experienced advisors offering a range of financial services, including investment management, financial and succession planning, philanthropic and specialty asset management, family office services, custom credit solutions, wealth structuring and family trust stewardship. I also serve as head of the Chief Investment Office (CIO) and the Investment Solutions Group (ISG) for Merrill Lynch Wealth Management and U.S. Trust. Together, the combined CIO and ISG teams deliver a disciplined investment process through industry-leading platforms, product capabilities and investment insights aligned to the goals-based approach and client experience framework. Previously, I was a member of the Global Diversity & Inclusion Council. During my tenure at Bank of America, I served as president of Global Wealth & Investment Management and president and CIO of Columbia Management. I joined Bank of America in 2004, following FleetBoston Financial’s merger with Bank of America. Previously, I held the roles of CIO and CEO of FleetBoston Financial’s asset management organization after joining the company in 2000. Prior to joining FleetBoston, I was a managing director and head of U.S. equity for JP Morgan Investment Management. During my 16-year career at JP Morgan, I served as global head of equity research, head of U.S. equity research and a portfolio manager, and equity research analyst for the chemical and textile industries. I began my career as an equity analyst at Home Insurance in 1981. I earned my bachelor’s degree in economics with high honors and Phi Beta Kappa from Rutgers University, and an MBA in finance from Columbia Business School. More Actions Natasha has a account Natasha Lamb Managing Partner, Director of Equity Research & Shareholder Engagement, Portfolio Manager, Arjuna Capital Arjuna Capital Bainbridge Graduate Institute Greater Boston Area 500+ 500+ connections Send InMail Natasha Lamb is the Director of Equity Research and Shareholder Engagement and a Portfolio Manager at Arjuna Capital, an investment advisor focused on sustainable and impact investing. Specializing in the integration of sustainability and shareholder value creation, Natasha integrates Environmental Social and Governance (ESG) factors into fundamental investment decisions, while engaging corporate leadership to improve performance through shareholder proposals, dialog, and public policy advocacy. Previously, Natasha was Vice President, Shareholder Advocacy and Corporate Engagement and an Equity Analyst at Trillium Asset Management. Natasha contributes thought leadership to the Guardian; as a Ceres Coalition member, advising corporate leadership; through the United Nations’ UNEP FI Climate Change Working Group; and as a founding organizer of Greater Boston Slow Money. In 2013 Natasha was nominated for the SRI service award for engaging natural gas companies on high global warming potential methane emissions. In 2014, her landmark negotiation with Exxon Mobil led to the company’s first public report on global warming and carbon asset risk. Natasha teaches sustainable investing at Bainbridge Graduate Institute where she sits on the Board Finance Committee. She is a trustee of The Food Project. Natasha holds an M.B.A in Sustainable Business from Bainbridge Graduate Institute, a pioneer in sustainable business education, and received her B.A. cum laude from Mount Holyoke College. Specialties: Sustainable and Responsible (SRI) Investing, Shareholder Engagement, Environmental Social & Governance (ESG) Analysis, Sustainability Consulting, Marketing Design & Presentation, Project Management, Sales See moreSee more of undefined summary Highlights Follow Follow Natasha’s Activity 532 followers ExxonMobil Dealt 'Watershed' Blow as Climate Change Proposal Wins Majority Backing Natasha liked Meet The New Breed Of Activist Investors Who Are Trying To Give Silicon Valley A Conscience Natasha liked Trump is out of touch with investors re #ParisAgreement. #ExxonVote underlines business case for #ClimateAction. Somaiya Institute Of Management Studies and Research Mumbai, Maharashtra, India 500+ 500+ connections Send InMail Highlights Follow Follow Saurabh’s Activity 521 followers SBI keen to take card arm public over the medium term Saurabh liked Shatabdi Express reached Pune right at 0030 hrs having got about an hour late that day sometime in May 2016. I came out of station and took an Auto Rickshaw. Out of habit, I started a small talk with the Driver: "What time do you go home? it's already 00.45 a.m?"I asked him. "Sir , I will return about 0400(a.m.) in the morning. " " Why do you drive in the night?" "Sir during the day I work in a company as a helper." "What are the timings? " "Sir, 0900 to 0600 p.m." " When do you rest?" "Sir I sleep from 0415 to 0730 a.m. & then from 07.30 p.m. till 10.30 p.m. after taking dinner early. And start auto-rickshaw by 11.00 p.m." " But then why so much effort?" "Sir, I have a son and a daughter. I want them to go to good schools and educate them well so that they will do better. Oh, the fees nowadays! So I have to do it; for them. In the night I earn more. That too is the reason, sir." "God bless you and your children!!"I said . I was wondering about all the talk on Work-Life Balance. Do you think a session on W/L balance would have helped him? He didn't need it. He was happy with his eyes set on his goal, all fired-up. Oh, how contextual everything is! Particularly W/L Balance. RS ( I have edited the post as I found leaving it open-ended meant failing to reach out properly.) Saurabh liked Is the BSE Sensex really overvalued? Saurabh shared this What should a financial model for solar look like? For me the first word that comes to mind when I think of solar is not renewable, not energy, not even returns. The word I associate foremost with solar is “simple”. Think about it, it’s the only form of electricity generation that doesn’t involve any moving parts (at least in its most basic form). I love peeling away layers and simplifying any thought, analysis or process. So I’m bemused when I see overly complicated financial analyses for solar. And I cringe when I see a financial analysis for solar shoehorned into a financial model for thermal. Not sure where this complication stems from but give me a relevant, easy to understand and actionable analysis any day. Introducing unrequired or thermal inspired complexity into the mix is just a giant diversionary smokescreen. There are only a handful of variables that are material for flexing to determine the shape and position of the returns curve for solar. And note that understanding this returns curve is key in a reverse auction situation (India), far more than in the case of FiT (pretty much RoW). Watch this space for a more detailed piece with my views on “Solar Financial Modeling” in the coming weeks following my recent Two Part series on “India Solar Tariffs”. Saurabh liked Me and my friend decided to travel in 'Auto' for a change. In an Auto Stand, we told an auto driver where we want to reach. He claimed 120 rupees for the same. We said, the place is very near by and he can come for 80 rupees. The first driver rejected our offer and the second one was adamant on 90 rupees. The third one in the Q agreed for 80 rupees. After getting into the auto, I asked him, 'Others are particular on their rates but you instantly agreed for our rate?'. He said, 'The auto stand gets very less customers because of Ola, Uber kind of services. I can't over rule before they both say No. The moment they said no, I grabbed the opportunity. These drivers will wait for hours together to get their 120 rupees. But I have now come for 80 rupees and while return, I will again find customer for another 80 rupees. So I will earn more than those stubborn drivers. Also what i negotiated with you can be adjusted with another customer. I will keep myself busy, at the same time flexible with customers and earn what I want. While getting down, I shake hands with the Management Guru in the Kakhi Uniform. Saurabh liked "What's your company's vision for the next 5 years?" Every time a potential employee or a new client or even some angels asks this question, I have to explain this to them: A vision is a long term plan. Any company goes through the famous 'J' curve when it starts off. You start low, dabble with ideas and go still lower along the J curve. You quickly morph and experiment with your services, throw beta versions and agile MVPs into the market, set up a voracious customer feedback loop in place and then figure out the correct revenue and market fit. It is AFTER all of this that you can plausibly have a concrete long term vision. Anything before that cannot really be termed as a 'vision'. Those are necessary short term tasks that you, along with your team, follow in order to GET a vision. More Actions Michael has a account Michael David Partner at Partners Private Equity LLC Partners Private Equity LLC University of Michigan - Stephen M. Ross School of Business Cleveland/Akron, Ohio Area 127 127 connections Send InMail Mike David is a Partner of Partners Private Equity LLC (PPE). Partners Private Equity is focused on acquisitions of established lower middle market businesses in sectors such as manufacturing, value added distribution and business services. In general we want to invest in companies that we can visit in a day trip by either road or air. We are primarily focused on middle market buyout transactions but will also pursue opportunistic special situations opportunities in unique circumstances. Transaction types include leveraged buyouts, corporate carve-outs, restructurings and selective minority investments. In general, our goal in any of these transaction types is to acquire an ownership stake in a viable, established business at a fair valuation. Prior to joining PPE, Mr. David was the founder and Managing Partner of Endurance Capital Advisors, LLC, an Akron, Ohio-based investment firm focused on publicly-traded small capitalization companies. Mr. David was responsible for all aspects of fund management, including capital raising, investment due diligence and selection, and portfolio management. Mr. David previously was Senior Vice President of CapitalWorks, LLC, a Cleveland, Ohio-based private equity firm specializing in middle market buyout transactions. At CapitalWorks, Mr. David was responsible for investment analysis, due diligence, portfolio management and performance reporting. Mr. David also led the firms’ efforts in starting and managing a long/short hedge fund. Mr. David’s career prior to CapitalWorks included managing the investment office for a high net worth family, Vice President of Finance & Accounting for a big-box sporting goods retail chain and Vice President of Quad-C, Inc., a private equity fund based in Charlottesville, VA. Mr. David received his BBA from Kent State University and his MBA from The University of Michigan. Somaiya Institute Of Management Studies and Research Mumbai, Maharashtra, India 500+ 500+ connections Send InMail Highlights Follow Follow Saurabh’s Activity 521 followers SBI keen to take card arm public over the medium term Saurabh liked Shatabdi Express reached Pune right at 0030 hrs having got about an hour late that day sometime in May 2016. I came out of station and took an Auto Rickshaw. Out of habit, I started a small talk with the Driver: "What time do you go home? it's already 00.45 a.m?"I asked him. "Sir , I will return about 0400(a.m.) in the morning. " " Why do you drive in the night?" "Sir during the day I work in a company as a helper." "What are the timings? " "Sir, 0900 to 0600 p.m." " When do you rest?" "Sir I sleep from 0415 to 0730 a.m. & then from 07.30 p.m. till 10.30 p.m. after taking dinner early. And start auto-rickshaw by 11.00 p.m." " But then why so much effort?" "Sir, I have a son and a daughter. I want them to go to good schools and educate them well so that they will do better. Oh, the fees nowadays! So I have to do it; for them. In the night I earn more. That too is the reason, sir." "God bless you and your children!!"I said . I was wondering about all the talk on Work-Life Balance. Do you think a session on W/L balance would have helped him? He didn't need it. He was happy with his eyes set on his goal, all fired-up. Oh, how contextual everything is! Particularly W/L Balance. RS ( I have edited the post as I found leaving it open-ended meant failing to reach out properly.) Saurabh liked Is the BSE Sensex really overvalued? Saurabh shared this What should a financial model for solar look like? For me the first word that comes to mind when I think of solar is not renewable, not energy, not even returns. The word I associate foremost with solar is “simple”. Think about it, it’s the only form of electricity generation that doesn’t involve any moving parts (at least in its most basic form). I love peeling away layers and simplifying any thought, analysis or process. So I’m bemused when I see overly complicated financial analyses for solar. And I cringe when I see a financial analysis for solar shoehorned into a financial model for thermal. Not sure where this complication stems from but give me a relevant, easy to understand and actionable analysis any day. Introducing unrequired or thermal inspired complexity into the mix is just a giant diversionary smokescreen. There are only a handful of variables that are material for flexing to determine the shape and position of the returns curve for solar. And note that understanding this returns curve is key in a reverse auction situation (India), far more than in the case of FiT (pretty much RoW). Watch this space for a more detailed piece with my views on “Solar Financial Modeling” in the coming weeks following my recent Two Part series on “India Solar Tariffs”. Saurabh liked Me and my friend decided to travel in 'Auto' for a change. In an Auto Stand, we told an auto driver where we want to reach. He claimed 120 rupees for the same. We said, the place is very near by and he can come for 80 rupees. The first driver rejected our offer and the second one was adamant on 90 rupees. The third one in the Q agreed for 80 rupees. After getting into the auto, I asked him, 'Others are particular on their rates but you instantly agreed for our rate?'. He said, 'The auto stand gets very less customers because of Ola, Uber kind of services. I can't over rule before they both say No. The moment they said no, I grabbed the opportunity. These drivers will wait for hours together to get their 120 rupees. But I have now come for 80 rupees and while return, I will again find customer for another 80 rupees. So I will earn more than those stubborn drivers. Also what i negotiated with you can be adjusted with another customer. I will keep myself busy, at the same time flexible with customers and earn what I want. While getting down, I shake hands with the Management Guru in the Kakhi Uniform. Saurabh liked "What's your company's vision for the next 5 years?" Every time a potential employee or a new client or even some angels asks this question, I have to explain this to them: A vision is a long term plan. Any company goes through the famous 'J' curve when it starts off. You start low, dabble with ideas and go still lower along the J curve. You quickly morph and experiment with your services, throw beta versions and agile MVPs into the market, set up a voracious customer feedback loop in place and then figure out the correct revenue and market fit. It is AFTER all of this that you can plausibly have a concrete long term vision. Anything before that cannot really be termed as a 'vision'. Those are necessary short term tasks that you, along with your team, follow in order to GET a vision. We have a talented mix of specialists with strong backgrounds in varying fields of the real estate sector ranging from interior design, project management, developing request for proposal documentation and bid evaluation work to financial modeling. We utilize our wide knowledge base according to client needs. Our mission is to help clients optimize efficient use of facilities and consult in strategic management and development of facilities. We have focused our expertise on serving the public sector. My role within Tilakonsultit is mainly to provide advisory services requiring financial modeling and/or optimizing of resources. Our management consulting service provides clients with analysis to support in strategic decision making. We have the capability to perform detailed analysis of our client's entire real estate portfolio. By calculating life span costs of alternative strategic decisions, we provide valuable information to our clients. Based on the data produced through our analysis, we are able to objectively evaluate whether facilities are in efficient use and determine if the real estate portfolio contains excess capacity. We provide our clients with concrete advice regarding which pieces of real estate serve a core purpose in producing the services required of the municipality and pin point those where cost savings are achievable.My main tasks include:- Building from scratch the models that form the basic tools of our management consulting service- Project work, from start to finish, including collecting data to writing client reports- Presenting results to clients and third parties (political decision makers)- Taking initiative in day-to-day tasks related to running a small company such as producing marketing material and updating the company home page- Contacting potential clients and managing existing client relationships Junior Equity Research Analyst Company Name Carnegie Investment Bank Dates Employed Apr 2014 – Feb 2016 Employment Duration 1 yr 11 mos Location Helsinki Area, Finland Carnegie is one of the leading investment banks in the Nordic region and a market leader in investment banking, securities and private banking. Pete McCarthy Associate at HOST Somerset November 11, 2016, Pete and Lauren were students together I met Lauren during her first year where she made regular contributions to the university's investment society. Her enthusiasm for business was clear to see, yet possessed a solid understanding of financial markets in relation to equity research. As the years have progressed she has consistently volunteered and put herself out there in organising events and supporting younger students. Lauren led her group stock pitch presentation which involved the 3D printing firm, Stratasys. With a recommendation to buy for the next 12-18 months based on fundamental financial analysis, her contribution was engaging and one could see that she enjoyed the challenge of presenting, taking questions and answering them in a structured manor. Lauren would be an asset to any team due to her positive can do mindset and her ability to think laterally when under pressure. View 1 more recommendation View 1 more recommendation recommendations Pete McCarthy Associate at HOST Somerset January 6, 2017, Lauren and Pete were students together I met Pete at the University’s Trading and Investment club in 2013. Throughout my years in the club I have worked alongside Pete on a number of projects, the most notable of which being Equity Research analysis. As part of the club's committee, Pete was a guiding figure for teams conducting equity research. Many of the younger members were new to the concept and thus Pete provided knowledgeable insight, guidance and mentorship to students of all disciplines throughout the duration of the equity research. As part of the equity research judging panel, Pete was able to provide valuable feedback for individuals, including myself, in terms of how to better their financial analysis and understanding of the company.Pete has always gone above and beyond his required role in the Trading and Investment Club and undoubtedly a role model for the younger students. On occasions when members would have questions and queries about topics covered in talks, Pete was always happy to take the time to explain and discuss further. Pete’s passion for economics and finance is clear to see, both in academia and beyond. Pete’s regular talks at the weekly club meetings as well as his economics and finance focused blog put a refreshing spin on current financial affairs. Pete would be a valuable asset to any company due to his highly motivated mindset, passion, and desire to achieve. I have no doubt that he will be highly successful in his chosen career path. Alex Martin Digital Marketing Specialist at Your Business Freedom✔Lead Generator✔Social Media Marketer✔Growth Maximizer✔ September 9, 2016, Alex worked with Lauren in the same group Alex successfully headed a group of five equity analysts, myself included, for an equity research project based on a 3D printing company, namely, Stratasys. The research spanned a total of three months and at the end the findings were pitched for investment. Throughout the duration, Alex's proved to be an outstanding facilitator, displaying enthusiasm and contributing important analytical expertise and industry insight to the group. Undoubtedly, Alex played a key role in the team's success.
